## Full Model Equation

\begin{equation}
N_{t+1, i, x} = \frac{
    \left[ k \displaystyle
        \sum_{g = 1}^{T_g} w_g \times \exp\left(- \displaystyle\frac{(\text{trait}_{i, g} - \text{env}_x)^2}{2\times \text{width}^2} \right) +
        H \sum_{h = 1}^{T_h} w_h \frac{\text{trait}_{i, h}}{\text{max}(\text{trait}_{i, h})} \right] \times N_{t, i, x}}{
    1 + A \left[ \displaystyle
        \sum_{j = 1, ~j \neq i}^{S} N_{t, j, x}  \left(1 - \sqrt{\sum_{c = 1}^{T_c} w_c \times (\text{trait}_{i, c} - \text{trait}_{j, c})^2} \right) +
        \frac{B}{A} \times N_{t,i,x} \right]
},
\end{equation}

with $w_g$, $w_h$ and $w_c$, the contribution respectively of trait to growth, hierarchical competition and limiting similarity with $T_g$, $T_h$ and $T_c$ the number of traits respectively contributing to growth, hierarchical competition and limiting similarity.

## Number of individuals in the special case of equilibrium in the optimal patch and without competition

We are here interested in solving analytically the number of individuals of a species in its optimal patch in a situation without any interspecific competition (limiting similarity and hierarchy).
Intraspecific competition $B$ is still acting.

When $A = H = 0$, the equation of the model becomes:
\begin{equation}
N_{t+1, i, x} = \frac{R_{i, x} \times N_{t, i, x}}{1+B \times N_{t, i, x}}
\end{equation}

When a species is in its optimal patch, we get $t_i - t_{opt} = 0$ and thus the
exponential term equals 1. Therefore we get:

\begin{equation}
R_{i, x} = k \times \exp\left(- \displaystyle\frac{(\text{trait}_{i, g} - \text{env}_x)^2}{2\times \text{width}^2} \right)
         = \exp(0)
         = 1
\end{equation}

and:
\begin{equation}
N_{t+1, i, x} = \frac{k \times N_{t, i, x}}{1+B \times N_{t, i, x}}
\end{equation}

At the equilibrium state we have:
\begin{equation}
N_{t+1, i, x} = N_{t, i, x}
\end{equation}

Thus we derive:
\begin{equation}
N_{t+1, i, x} = \frac{k \times N_{t, i, x}}{1+B \times N_{t, i, x}}
=> 1 = \frac{k}{1 + B \times N_{t, i, x}}
=> k = 1 + B \times N_{t, i, x}
\end{equation}

In the end, we obtain:
\begin{equation}
N_{t, i, x} = \frac{k-1}{B}
\end{equation}

With example values of $k=1.15$ and $B=10e-4$, the number of individuals of a
species in its optimal patch should therefore be:

\begin{equation}
N_{eq, i, x} = \frac{0.15}{10e-4} = 1500
\end{equation}
